summary: H. Clark Schor is mentioned in three memoranda from January 1978, all addressed to SA/DO/O. In these memos, Schor provides additional information in response to a request from the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). The information pertains to individuals and entities of interest to the HSCA, detailing the types and quantity of documents held by the Central Cover Staff (CCS) on each. The memos specifically reference files on George DeMohrenschildt, Leo Cherne, William Harvey, the International Rescue Committee, Richard Helms, James Angleton, Raymond Rocca, and the Wackenhut Corporation. Schor's role appears to be facilitating the HSCA's investigation by providing details about relevant files held by the CCS.
significance: H. Clark Schor's significance in the JFK context lies in his role as a point of contact within the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) who provided information to the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) regarding individuals and organizations of interest to their investigation. His memos detail the availability of CIA files related to key figures and entities connected to the JFK assassination, indicating his involvement in the process of making CIA information accessible to the HSCA.
